node.text:
People everywhere are thinking about quitting their jobs. But how do you decide if it's the right move for you? And if you do decide to quit, how do you give your notice and leave gracefully?

Editor Amy Gallo dug into the HBR archive to surface our best advice on quitting the right way — from figuring out how to tell your boss to how much notice to give. Learn more in the video above.

node.text:
It’s easy to feel demoralized when career progress is slow. Many of us are left wondering: Is my plan not working — or just not working yet?

Dorie Clark, a marketing strategist who has authored more than 200 HBR articles, argues that to build the career you want, you have to be willing to work the process. And it's often a long one.

HBR editor @ramsey.online spoke with @dorieclark on Instagram Live about how to know when to keep plugging along — and when it's time to move on.

You can watch the recording above ⬆️ and read more in the Clark's new article "Feeling Stuck or Stymied?" and her upcoming book "The Long Game."

node.text:
Hey! I’m Kelsey — host of “Career Crush,” a new series from @HBRAscend.

Organizations like the ACLU, and the amazing people who work for them, have been in the headlines more than ever as they continue to fight for things like free speech, LGBTQ+ rights, and police accountability.

I’m passionate about these causes. I can attend protests and sign petitions all day long, but in the end, it is the attorneys working in public interest law that will help to turn the changes I want to see into realities.

To learn more, I spoke with Jessica Lewis, a Staff Attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts. Jessica shared with me the details about her career — from interning at the White House, to attending Harvard Law School, to working at the Southern Poverty Law Center, to becoming an attorney at the ACLU.

We also talked about the pay discrepancy between “big law” and public interest law, the pros and cons of following your passion, and what it really takes to change the world.

I’m really curious: Do you have a career crush? Let me know who they are in the comments (or tag your crush directly). I’d love to hear about them!

If you liked this episode, you can subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more content @hbrascend! Thanks for watching.

node.title: What It’s Like to Be a Social Justice Lawyer

node.text:
Giving two-weeks’ notice is standard in the United States, where at-will employment reigns supreme. But what if there was a better way — for both workers and companies?

@robertglazer_, CEO and founder of the global marketing agency Acceleration Partners, champions a culture where safe, open conversations about career trajectories between employees and managers are commonplace — and where employees feel comfortable speaking up when it's time for them to start looking for their next opportunity.

HBR associate editor @ramsey.online spoke with Robert on Instagram Live about how his company's transition program eliminates the element of surprise when an employee is moving on. Watch the video above, and read more about the topic in his article on HBR.org:

"The ‘Two Weeks’ Notice’ Approach to Changing Jobs Is Bad for Companies and Employees”

node.text:
Hey! I’m Kelsey — host of “Career Crush,” a new series from @HBRAscend.

I am fascinated by coding. It's everywhere! Every single one of the digital experiences we enjoy is the result of code. But honestly, I know almost nothing about how it works or how the people behind the code — software engineers — do what they do.

To find out, I spoke with Lindsey Redd.

Lindsey has coded for some of the coolest tech companies in the world: Slack, Lyft, and now Stripe. She shared with me the details of her journey — from wanting to be a doctor, to studying computer science at Stanford, to thriving in the top echelons of software engineering. We also talked about some common misconceptions about software engineers, what it’s like to work in a predominately white and male industry, and how to nail an interview for a job like hers.

I’m really curious: Do you have a career crush? Let me know who they are in the comments (or tag your crush directly). I’d love to hear about them!

If you liked this episode, you can subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more content @hbrascend!

node.title: What Is It Like to Be a Software Engineer? | Career Crush

node.text:
Yesterday on Instagram Live, HBR editor @ramsey.online spoke with @lilyzheng308, a diversity, equity, and inclusion strategist. He asked: What does it mean to be an ally, advocate, and activist today — especially as more and more companies are focused on DE&I? And how can each of us help serve those who are underrepresented? See our video above to watch the discussion.

Articles by Lily Zheng on HBR.org:

"It's Not Your Coworkers' Job to Teach You About Social Issues"

"How to Show White Men That Diversity and Inclusion Efforts Need Them"

"Adapt Your D&I Efforts to the Reality of the Crisis"

"We're Entering the Age of Corporate Social Justice"

"Do Your Employees Feel Safe Reporting Abuse and Discrimination?"

"Transgender, Gender-Fluid, Nonbinary, and Gender-Nonconforming Employees Deserve Better Policies"

"To Dismantle Anti-Asian Racism, We Must Understand Its Roots"

"Your Rainbow Logo Doesn't Make You an Ally"

node.text:
Hey! I’m Kelsey — host of “Career Crush,” a new series from @HBRAscend.
What’s a career crush? It’s a platonic crush you develop on someone who has a really cool job and is doing really cool things. In this episode, I interviewed one of my career crushes, Dave Jorgenson (@dave.jorgenson), to get to the bottom of what it’s like to be a full-time TikTok producer.

Dave's entire job is to make TikToks for the @washingtonpost. And his videos hit the mark — they're consistently informative, funny, and on-trend. I've always wondered: How does he do it? How does he continue to make hilarious, news-centered videos every day? What is it like to make TikToks for a living?

I sat down with Dave to chat with him about his journey from interning at The Colbert Report, to making YouTube videos, to becoming the newspaper-hat-wearing TikToker. We discussed his creative process, how he turned his job into one he loves, and how he helped The Washington Post’s TikTok reach almost one million followers.

I’m also really curious: Do you have a career crush? Let me know who they are in the comments (or tag your crush directly). I’d love to hear about them!

If you liked this episode, you can subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more content @hbrascend! Thanks for watching 🤗

node.title: What It’s Like to Make TikToks for a Living

node.text:
Women are often told that if they can fix their imposter syndrome, they'd be more successful in their careers. But is it really a lack of confidence holding them back — or is it systemic bias?

Today we spoke with @jodiannburey and @rtulshyan, HBR authors working to debunk the idea that imposter syndrome is a problem that's on individuals to solve. They argue that the “diagnosis” of imposter syndrome is problematic because it fails to acknowledge the historical and cultural contexts that affect the way women are treated — especially women of color.

Watch the full live conversation with HBR editor @ramsey.online here and add any questions you have about the topic in the comments.

Find the articles on HBR.org:

"Stop Telling Women They Have Imposter Syndrome"

"End Imposter Syndrome in Your Workplace"

node.text:
Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

In this episode, “How to Get Out of a Creative Rut,” I come face-to-face with my biggest demon: feeling mentally blocked. Some days I feel extremely inspired and productive; then there are others when I’m convinced I have no more ideas left in my brain. Nada. Nothing. Nope.

To help, I confessed my anxieties to entrepreneur @sonjarasula, who reassured me that creative ruts happen to everyone and they are completely normal (and expected). She offered ideas on how to reset ourselves to escape the typical creative rut, and strategies to prevent a bigger creative crisis down the line.
I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend.

node.title: How to Get Out of a Creative Rut

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

There are plenty of challenges when it comes to trusting colleagues, especially in a world with hybrid offices and remote teams. Do people trust me? How can I make sure there’s trust on my team? And what can I do if trust is broken?

In this episode, “How to Build — and Repair — Trust at Work,” @LSU_slhrd professor Tyree Mitchell and I explore the building blocks of trust, how to embed it in a work culture, and what to do when it breaks down.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend. ✌️

node.title: How to Build — and Repair — Trust at Work

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine — host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend. In this episode, I’m looking for a better way to give difficult feedback.

Giving feedback can feel like a real struggle. The last thing I want to do is hurt someone's feelings, and in the spirit of “not rocking the boat,”  I sometimes put off giving necessary feedback, which inevitably makes things worse (and more awkward) over time. Other times, I might be motivated to speak up, but my words inadvertently come off the wrong way and put the other person in a hardened defensive mode.

With the help of author Liane Davey (@lianedavey), I learn the key four steps of delivering constructive, useful feedback. It all makes sense when Liane explains that feedback isn’t really about the other person — it’s about YOU! (Trust me, just watch.)

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend. ✌️

node.title: How to Give Feedback — Especially When You’re Dreading It

node.text:
👋 Hi, I'm Christine, host of “Christine vs. Work,” a series for our new brand @HBRAscend.

In this episode, “You Need Tough Feedback — Here's How to Get It,” I investigate the best way to get quality feedback so I can improve and grow in my role. But there are plenty of challenges. Sometimes feedback can feel shallow and vague (“Good job!”). Other times I find myself blindsided by unexpected criticism. And if I get feedback that’s tough to swallow, what’s the best way to respond?

With the help of career coach Octavia Goredema (@octaviagoredema), I learn how to best prepare for feedback, strategies for finding time and space for listening and reflection, and ways to build the foundation for ongoing constructive dialogue.

I’m curious: What other work topics would you like me to tackle next? I read every comment and would love to hear from you.

Don’t miss new Season 2 episodes of “Christine vs. Work.” Subscribe to the series on our YouTube channel, and check out more Ascend content @HBRAscend. ✌️

node.title: You Need Tough Feedback — Here’s How to Get It

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'McKinsey estimates a $220 billion annual wage disparity between Black and white Americans. Black workers are disproportionately represented in low-wage jobs, underrepresented in high-wage jobs, and are paid less, on average, than white workers in the same roles. Adapted from "Closing the Job Mobility Gap Between Black and White Americans," by Shelley Stewart III et al.'.

node.text:
New research from McKinsey finds critical gaps that Black Americans face not only as workers, but also as business owners, savers and investors, consumers, and residents that prevent full participation in the U.S. economy and significantly limit economic mobility.

While these gaps are substantial, the research suggests ways to close them.

Two initiatives, in particular, could make a big difference: unblocking pipelines into higher-paying professions and creating new career pathways from lower-paying occupations.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

Adapted from "Closing the Job Mobility Gap Between Black and White Americans," by Shelley Stewart III et al.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR STRATEGY "Traditional corporate social responsibility and philanthropy are inadequate for our times. Leaders must rethink what a business is and how it drives change in the world." Read the full article, "The Net Positive Manifesto," by Paul Polman and Andrew Winston'.

node.text:
"Companies that have embraced action on environmental, social, and governance issues are outpacing their competitors," write consultant and author Andrew Winston and former Unilever CEO Paul Polman. "Businesses that thrive in this new environment will look different from those of the past."

Tap the link in our bio to read Polman and Winston's vision of a "net positive" company.

Adapted from "The Net Positive Manifesto," by Paul Polman and Andrew Winston. Artist credit: Guillaume Kurkdjian.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 01, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR STRATEGY "Traditional corporate social responsibility and philanthropy are inadequate for our times. Leaders must rethink what a business is and how it drives change in the world." Read the full article, "The Net Positive Manifesto," by Paul Polman and Andrew Winston'.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on September 01, 2021.
Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'How to Ask a Colleague to Mask Up It doesn't have to be an awkward conversation.'.

node.text:
A person may show up at work maskless for any number of reasons. They might have simply gotten back into old habits and forgotten. They might not know what your business’s current masking policy is. They might see a masking recommendation as just that — a recommendation — and decide against it, or even blatantly disagree with it.

Whatever their reason, you may nonetheless prefer that they mask up around you. Or, you may find yourself in the position of needing to enforce a broader masking policy.

How should you approach the conversation? Tap the link in our bio for some strategies.

Adapted from, "How to Ask a Colleague to Mask Up," by Vanessa Bohns.

Artist credit: HBR Staff/lakshmiprasad/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'How to Ask a Colleague to Mask Up It doesn't have to be an awkward conversation.'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 31, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'OHBR DIFFICULT CONVERSATIONS "As many Covid related restrictions are in flux and the Delta variant rages on, companies are facing the challenge of getting people who have stopped masking elsewhere to mask up in the office." Read the full article, "How to Ask a Colleague to Mask Up," by Vanessa Bohns'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HBR MANAGING PEOPLE "More than 40% ofU.S. employees would start looking for another job or quit immediately if ordered to return to the office full time." Read the full article, "Don't Force People to Come Back to the Office Full Time," by Jose Maria Barrero et al.'.

node.text:
Companies such as Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan have recently moved their workforces back into the office full-time, citing the promises of more collaboration and better productivity.

But a monthly survey of 5,000 Americans shows that employees want to work from home 2.5 days per week on average. Nearly 80% want to WFH at least one day per week. And the June and July surveys revealed that more than 40% of U.S. employees would start looking for another job or quit immediately if ordered to return to the office full time.

If companies insist on sending people back to the office, they face a major threat to retention — and a threat to diversity. The survey data show that people of color and highly educated women with young children in particular value the ability to work from home part of the week. A ban on working from home risks a rush to the exit by these employees.

Head to the link in our bio to read more of the data on remote work preferences — and why more companies need to start listening.

Adapted from "Don’t Force People to Come Back to the Office Full Time," by Jose Maria Barrero, Nicholas Bloom, and Steven J. Davis.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 29, 2021. May be an image of cloud and text that says 'Why You Need to Protect Your Sense of Wonder Especially Now Lessons from a physician and a psychologist on cultivating awe.'.

node.text:
As the pandemic goes on, now more than ever we need ways to refresh our energies, calm our anxieties, and nurse our well-being. One potentially powerful intervention that is rarely talked about in the workplace: the cultivation of experiences of awe. Like gratitude and curiosity, awe can leave us feeling inspired and energized.

Experiencing awe also has other benefits: 

✨ It actively reduces stress.

✨ It decreases distracting mental chatter and rumination.

✨ It stimulates new ways of thinking.

✨ It helps us build relationships.

✨ It inspires generosity and compassion.

Tap the link in our bio to learn how to cultivate experiences of awe during the course of your workday. 

Adapted from "Why You Need to Protect Your Sense of Wonder — Especially Now,” by David P. Fessell and Karen Reivich. Art credit: HBR Staff/Boris Zhitkov/Micha Pawlitzki/Getty Images.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Problem with Saying "It's No Big Deal" Are you overlooking serious problems because you're conflict averse?'.

node.text:
Your colleague disappoints you by missing a deadline. Your boss makes an inappropriate comment about how you look. A client makes an unreasonable demand of your team.

In each case, you’re upset or angry about what’s happened — a natural response to a violation of your values — but, rather than saying or doing something about it, you tell yourself: "It’s no big deal.” But that negative feeling doesn't go away so quickly.

When you don’t address something early on, there’s a good chance you’ll harbor negative emotional energy and become so upset that you eventually have a hard time being in the same room with the person who “wronged” you — let alone trusting them or working productively with them.

Tap the link in our bio for tips on what to do and say instead of "It's no big deal."

Adapted from "The Problem with Saying 'It’s No Big Deal,'" by James R. Detert. Artist credit: malerapaso/Getty Images.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Problem with Saying "It's No Big Deal" Are you overlooking serious problems because you're conflict averse?'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'OHBR MANAGING CONFLICTS "Not everything that triggers an an emotional reaction requires a response. But if something is really no big deal, then you probably wouldn't use this rationalization in the first place; you'd simply address it or ignore it." Read the full article, "The Problem with Saying 'It's No Big Deal," by James R. Detert'.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'OHBR HIRING "If you let hiring managers screen social media profiles, it will absolutely result in bias." Read the full article "Stop Screening Û Job Candidates' Social Media," by HBR Editors'.

node.text:
According to a 2018 survey, 70% of employers check out applicants’ profiles as part of their screening process, and 54% have rejected applicants because of what they found.

New research suggests that hiring managers who take this approach should use caution: Much of what they dig up is information they are ethically discouraged or legally prohibited from taking into account when evaluating candidates — and little of it is predictive of performance.

In the first of three studies, the researchers examined the Facebook pages of 266 U.S. job seekers. A significant share of profiles contained details that companies may be legally prohibited from considering, including gender, race, and ethnicity; disabilities; pregnancy status; sexual orientation; political views; and religious affiliation. Many of the job seekers’ profiles also included information of potential concern to prospective employers, such as profanity, gambling, alcohol consumption, and referenced drug use.

In the second study, the researchers explored whether such information affects recruiters’ evaluations. Recruiters were swayed by factors that are supposedly off-limits, such as relationship status — married and engaged candidates got higher marks, on average, than their single counterparts. Older individuals were also rated more highly, women had an advantage, and candidates who indicated their religious beliefs got lower ratings. Factors such as profanity, alcohol or drug use, violence, and sexual behavior lowered ratings.

Learn more about the research at the link in our bio.

Adapted from "Stop Screening Job Candidates’ Social Media,” by HBR Editors.

node.text:
It’s easy to feel demoralized when career progress is slow. Many of us are left wondering: Is my plan not working — or just not working yet?

Dorie Clark, a marketing strategist who has authored more than 200 HBR articles, argues that to build the career you want, you have to be willing to work the process. And it's often a long one.

HBR editor @ramsey.online spoke with @dorieclark on Instagram Live about how to know when to keep plugging along — and when it's time to move on.

You can watch the recording above ⬆️ and read more in the Clark's new article "Feeling Stuck or Stymied?" and her upcoming book "The Long Game."

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 24, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HB MANAGING YOURSELF "After a year of so much disruption, grief, and anxiety, taking time away from work and your responsibilities is especially important." Read the full article, "We All Really Need a Vacation. Here's How to Make the Most of It.' by Art Markman'.

node.text:
Have you taken a vacation this summer? If not, chances are you could use some time off to recharge. And there are several benefits.

For one, rest and time away can increase resilience, which will make you better able to deal with setbacks at work and in life. Vacations also give you a new perspective, which can help you identify novel solutions to problems. 

To make the most of your vacation, consider taking at least a week away from home (especially if your home is also now your office). Prepare your clients and colleagues early, and stay off your phone as much as possible. If you can’t go far or take multiple days off, remember that one-off personal days and long weekends can hugely helpful for taking a breather or connecting with friends and family.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full article, "We All Really Need a Vacation. Here’s How to Make the Most of It." by Art Markman.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 23, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, dog and text that says 'How to Work with Someone Who Creates Unnecessary Conflict Don't let them waste your precious time, trust, or energy.'.

node.text:
Disagreements on a team aren’t necessarily a bad thing. But you want to watch out for unhealthy conflicts that hijack precious time, trust, and energy. Often this type of animosity develops when there’s a “conflict entrepreneur” on your team — someone who inflames conflict for their own ends.

Tap the link in our bio to read about how to handle this type of coworker, boss, or employee.

Adapted from "How to Work with Someone Who Creates Unnecessary Conflict," by Amanda Ripley. Artist credit: Fernando Trabanco Fotografía/Getty Images.

Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 22, 2021. May be an image of ocean and text that says 'Don't Let Power Corrupt You How to exercise influence -without losing your moral compass.'.

node.text:
Power is essential to taking charge and driving change, but it makes leaders vulnerable to two traps that can not only erode their own effectiveness, but also undermine their team’s.

First, it’s easy to fall victim to hubris, the excessive pride and self-confidence that can come with power. Consider a study in which some participants were asked to write about a time when they felt powerful while others wrote about feeling powerless. All were then given a die, offered a reward for correctly predicting the outcome of a roll, and asked if they wanted to throw the die themselves or have the experimenter do it. Only 58% of those who had written about feeling powerless rolled for themselves, while every single participant who wrote about feeling powerful did so. Simply recalling an experience of power can lead people to greatly overestimate their abilities, even to the extent of thinking they can affect a random roll of a die.

The second trap involves self-focus. People at the top tend to become less attentive to subordinates — and can’t be bothered to understand the ways the people under them work together. Not “seeing” the people you lead diminishes effectiveness all around. People aren’t motivated or able to contribute their best efforts if they perceive that you are disconnected from and uninterested in them.

To effectively exercise power while avoiding its pitfalls, leaders must cultivate humility as an antidote to hubris and empathy as an antidote to self-focus. Head to the link in our bio to learn how.

Adapted from "Don't Let Power Corrupt You," by Julie Battilana and Tiziana Casciaro. Art credit: Dave Sandford.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Harvard Business Review on August 19, 2021. May be an image of dog and text that says 'Compassion and Accountability Aren't Mutually Exclusive How to be a caring and thoughtful leader while holding your team to high standards.'.

node.text:
It’s been a terrible year for most people. And now that pandemic restrictions are lifting in many parts of the world, some managers are wondering how to continue to balance compassion for the people on their team and accountability for getting work done.

It's possible to have both. Rather than thinking of it as a trade-off between compassion and accountability, think about how you can combine the two. Here are eight steps managers can take to meet goals while also being caring:

❤️ Reframe how you think about the last year. Don't think about what you didn't get done — focus on what do you did accomplish.

❤️ Reframe how you think about motivating employees. Many managers believe they need to be tough to get people to produce, but the research doesn’t support that.

❤️ Don't ignore the reality. People are struggling with mental health and that needs to be acknowledged.

❤️ Remember everyone's situation is unique. Don't think that just because you are getting through things, everyone else should be able to match your output.

❤️ Foster resilience. Show your team the progress they've made and reconnect them to the purpose of their work.

❤️ Have individual conversations and plans. Figure out what's most feasible for each person.

❤️ Take it to the group. Ask them: “OK, let’s assume these are the conditions we have to work under for another six months. How can we best do our work? And how can we improve our work together?”

❤️ Take care of yourself. It's hard to do that while caring for your employees. Get a good night’s sleep, eat well, exercise, and make sure you have the support you need.

Adapted from "Managers: Compassion and Accountability Aren’t Mutually Exclusive," by Amy Gallo. Art credit: alexsalcedo/Getty Images.
